entry.title: Combined summary - Trustless 2-way-peg without softfork
entry.summary: The first part of the email contains a request for a brief explanation of how a protocol called "Prometheus" works. The requester specifically asks for details on how the protocol achieves consensus on the correctness of a state reported by an oracle in a permissionless, anonymous, and decentralized manner.The second part of the email discusses an article that focuses on proving the existence and uniqueness of the Nash equilibrium in a protocol model. The author introduces the concept of a protocol game, which represents interactions between multiple agents in a distributed system. Key components of the protocol model, such as players, strategies, and payoffs, are defined. The importance of proving the existence and uniqueness of the Nash equilibrium is emphasized to ensure stability and efficiency in the protocol model.To prove the existence of the Nash equilibrium, the author introduces the idea of best response dynamics, where players iteratively choose strategies that maximize their payoffs given the choices of other players. The article explains how this iterative process converges to a Nash equilibrium under certain conditions. The concept of potential games, which are special games where differences in payoffs only depend on the difference in the number of players choosing specific strategies, is also discussed. Potential games provide a framework for proving the existence and uniqueness of the Nash equilibrium in the protocol model.The article includes examples and case studies to illustrate the concepts and techniques discussed. It also provides links to additional resources and research papers for further reading. Overall, the article offers a comprehensive overview of proofs for the Nash equilibrium in the protocol model, providing valuable insights for those interested in game theory and distributed systems.Moving on to the second topic in the email, the Prometheus protocol is introduced. This protocol enables high-load computing on top of the Bitcoin network in a censorship-resistant manner. It operates as a multi-party game where an oracle, referred to as a "worker," is assigned computationally complex tasks. The network then reaches a consensus on whether the result reported by the worker is true.The Prometheus protocol is considered cryptoeconomically safe, as it has a proven Nash equilibrium. It does not require any soft forks and can be implemented with just a few Bitcoin transactions per task. All economic transactions within the protocol are conducted using Bitcoin as a means of payment, leveraging existing Bitcoin script capabilities.Originally proposed by the Pandora Project team, the Prometheus protocol has been transferred to the LNP/BP Standards Association for potential future use as a layer on top of Bitcoin. However, the author of the email recently realized that the Prometheus protocol can also be utilized to build a trustless 2-way peg on the Bitcoin blockchain without necessitating any soft forks. In this scenario, the worker acts as an oracle for another Bitcoin system, such as a sidechain or client-side validated protocol, and the protocol ensures consensus on the correctness of the state reported by the oracle.This alternative approach to 2-way pegs opens up possibilities for trustless transfers of Bitcoins between the Bitcoin blockchain, RGB, and potentially a new layer 1 called "prime." To delve deeper into the concept of the prime layer, the author recommends checking out their Baltic Honeybadger talk.In summary, the email introduces the Prometheus protocol for high-load computing on Bitcoin, highlights its cryptoeconomic safety, and explains how it can be used for trustless 2-way pegs without requiring any soft forks. The author provides links to the protocol paper and additional resources for further information.
